summary: This is a sealed order by Magistrate Judge Sarah Netburn denying a motion by the U.S. Attorney's Office to modify a protective order from a civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Jeffrey Epstein) to allow a law firm to comply with a grand jury subpoena. The court finds the government failed to show exceptional circumstances or compelling need to override the confidentiality protections relied upon by the parties in their settlement.

persons.name: Sarah Netburn
persons.context: Issued the sealed order denying the government's motion to modify a protective order to allow compliance with a grand jury subpoena in the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of a federal grand jury investigation for possible violations of sex trafficking laws, and a defendant in the settled civil case Jane Doe 43 v. Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jane Doe 43
persons.context: The plaintiff in the settled civil suit against Jeffrey Epstein, whose confidential discovery materials are protected by the order the government seeks to modify.

connections.description: Jane Doe 43 was the plaintiff in a civil suit against Jeffrey Epstein alleging sex trafficking.
The law firm represented Jane Doe 43 in the civil suit against Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: A protective order was issued in the civil case Jane Doe 43 v. Jeffrey Epstein, et al., designating certain discovery material as confidential.

events.title: Court Denies Motion to Modify Protective Order
events.description: Magistrate Judge Sarah Netburn denies the U.S. Attorney's motion to modify the protective order to allow a law firm to comply with a grand jury subpoena for confidential civil discovery materials.

events.title: Settlement of Civil Case
events.description: The civil case Jane Doe 43 v. Jeffrey Epstein settled, foreclosing the possibility of a trial and the public disclosure of confidential materials.

events.title: Grand Jury Investigation
events.description: An ongoing federal grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for possible violations of sex trafficking laws (Title 18, U.S.C. §§ 1591, 1594(c), 2422(b)).

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office sought to bypass a protective order from a settled civil sex trafficking case to obtain confidential discovery materials via grand jury subpoena.
Magistrate Judge Sarah Netburn denied the motion, finding the government failed to demonstrate the 'exceptional circumstances' or 'compelling need' required to modify such an order.
The court found the parties' reliance on the protective order's confidentiality was reasonable, especially since the case settled, preventing any trial where materials might become public.
The order reveals an active federal grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking violations as of April 2019.
The decision highlights tension between grand jury secrecy and the confidentiality protections relied upon by parties to settle civil litigation.
